heading: positive start to trading week
subheading: u.s. stocks headed upward, buoyed by good news for blue chips, optimism over tech and net stocks, and waning fears of a fed interest rate hike.
author: wired staff
text: new york -- u.s. stocks rose on monday, led by cigarette and food maker philip morris cos. inc. and health care giant johnson & johnson as investors bet the federal reserve will not raise interest rates at a meeting this week. the market was also underpinned by gains in software, computer, biotechnology and banking issues."investors seem to have gotten over their worries about the internet sector, which plagued (the market) on friday, and, in general, the market is feeling much better," said charlie crane, chief market strategist at key asset management.on friday, shares in internet retailer amazon.com plunged following a series of negative comments by analysts.a big gain in the stock of philip morris buoyed the blue-chip dow jones industrial average as traders cheered news overnight that the company had reached a deal to buy nabisco holdings, maker of brands such as oreo cookies and grey poupon mustard, for $14.9 billion. philip morris (mo) jumped 3-13/16 to 27-1/4.johnson & johnson also rallied sharply, helping bolster blue chip stocks, after painewebber announced it had added the company to the brokerage's "highlighted stocks" list. painewebber also upgraded its rating on the company's stock to buy from neutral and raised its price target to $115 from $93. johnson & johnson (jnj) was up 5-3/4 to 95-1/2.based on early and unofficial closing figures, the dow jones industrial average ended up 138.24 points, or 1.33 percent, at 10,542.99. the technology-dominated nasdaq composite index climbed 66.78 points, or 1.74 percent, to 3,912.12.among the computer issues to advance, were international business machines (ibm) up 3-3/8 at 115-1/8, and hewlett-packard (hwp), which gained 3-1/16 at 120. even amazon (amzn) steadied, ending up 1/16 at 33-15/16.the market's main focus remained on the fed's policy-setting meeting on tuesday and wednesday when the central bank will decide whether or not to hike interest rates again. it has increased rates six times since last june amid concern that the u.s. economy is overheating to such an extent that it is going to lead to an acceleration in inflation.experts are widely predicting the fed will stay its hand on interest rates, although a growing number now see more credit tightening before the year's end."people are expecting no change in rates, so any surprise there could cause the market to react on the downside," said james volk, co-director of institutional trading at d.a. davidson and co.broader measures of the stock market were also higher. the standard & poor's 500 ended up 13.83 points, or 0.96 percent, at 1,455.31.
